Here we present the method of moments, another routine estimation approach in the statistical literature for estimating the model parameters in the SIR model ( 1). During the early phase of an epidemic, one may assume S( t)/ N≈1 and set dt=1 (e.g. a time unit of 1 day for discretisation), so that the second ODE of ( 1) leads to the approximate exponential function solution:
I ( t ) ≈ I ( 0 ) exp { ( β − γ ) t } ,
t = 1 , … , T ,
where without loss of generality I(0)>0 (otherwise time 0 may be redefined in the time series), and T is the last observation time of data collection. Taking the logarithmic transformation, we obtain
ln I ( t ) ≈ ln I ( 0 ) + ( β − γ ) t , which provides a linear mean model with intercept parameter
ln I ( 0 ) and slope parameter ( β− γ) of the covariate time. This slope parameter may be estimated by the least squares method. Likewise, γ may be estimated through another similar approximated linear relationship (without intercept) of the form: Δ R( t)= R( t+1)− R( t)≈ γI( t), from the third ODE of the SIR model ( 1) at discrete times at which data are actually recorded. After estimate
γ
